title: 106_hr2140
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. Congress finds that the Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area in Georgia is a significant resource adversely affected by land use changes. The expanding population of metropolitan Atlanta threatens the protection of the scenic, recreational, natural, and historical values of the area. Georgia's Metropolitan River Protection Act aims to safeguard the corridor along the Chattahoochee River. The Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area faces threats from land use changes due to the expanding population of metropolitan Atlanta. The State of Georgia and political subdivisions along the river are willing to cooperate with the United States to establish linear corridors linking existing units of the recreation area. Congress may appropriate funds to support this cooperative effort. The cooperative effort to protect the Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area will be funded by various sources, including the State, private foundations, and corporate entities. The purposes of the Act are to enhance visitor enjoyment, standardize management of the area, and allocate Federal funds for costs. The cooperative effort to expand the Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area will involve sharing costs among Federal, State, local, and private entities to create linear corridors connecting existing units and protecting open spaces along the river corridor. The Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area Act is being amended to involve a cooperative effort among various entities to expand the recreation area and protect open spaces along the river corridor. The Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area Act is being amended to modify boundaries and expand the recreation area with the cooperation of various entities. The Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area boundaries can be modified to include additional land by the Secretary after consultation with stakeholders. The revised boundaries will take effect unless Congress disapproves within 180 days. The maximum acreage limit is increased to 10,000 acres. The Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area boundaries can be expanded to 10,000 acres. Amendments include acquiring property from willing sellers and entering cooperative agreements with Georgia and other entities. The Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area boundaries may be expanded to 10,000 acres through acquiring property and entering cooperative agreements with Georgia and other entities. Funding for this expansion is addressed in an amendment to the Act. Funding sources and a general management plan are addressed in an amendment to the Act. The amendment increases funding to $115,000,000 and allows the Secretary to accept donations for the Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area. Additionally, funds from the amendment are in addition to other funding sources from various entities. Subsection (c) is also revised for clarity. The Secretary will encourage public participation from various entities in preparing the revised plan for the Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area in Georgia.
